Description: Body sherd of Chian pottery Type B1 kantharos; white slip; interior glazed black; lotus flower in added white outline with added red centres above two white lines; below at bottom of sherd, single white band; exterior: reserved save for pre-firing inscription; short horizontal strokes on handle.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University College London. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Many kantharoi Type B1 (See Williams, D. ‘Aigina, Aphaia-Tempel 5. The pottery from Chios’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 1983, 169) have painted inscriptions beneath the rim and several have been found on Aegina as well as at Naukratis. Kantharoi Type B1 also have lotus flowers and lotus buds on the interior above two white bands. The exterior and interior surfaces of the sherd were burnt during the bombings in London in 1941.
See also Johnston, Bulletin of the Institute of Classical Studies 29 (1982) 40.
Bibliographic references: Johnston 1978 / Pottery from Naukratis: An Exhibition on the Occasion of the 11th International Congress of Classical Archaeology (no. 9)
Johnston 2006b / The Delta: From Gamma to Zeta (p. 23, fig. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1866) (phase 2)
